The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Chancellor of the Exchequer (CP.-169 (31))on the subject of the Franco-American agreement about the Hoover Plan.As the Memorandum had only been circulated late on the previous evening, the Chancellor of theExchequer gave the Cabinet a detailed commentaryon the Agreement, in the course of which he emphasised the difficulties to this country arisingout of the points left over for settlement.The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that on the previous day hehad suggested that a point had now been reachedwhen a Conference should immediately be assembledin London in accordance with the invitation issuedas the result of the Cabinet Conclusion referredto in the margin. He had suggested that, in thefirst instance, an Expert Conference shouldassemble on Monday, July 13th, to be followed bya meeting of Ministers a week later, so as not tointerfere with the Paris and Berlin visits. Heread, a reply which he had just received from theFrench Government (telegram No .155 from the british ambassador, Paris) accepting the British suggestion in principle, but proposing that the Experts should meet on July 17th, and that the date of themeeting of the Conference of Ministers should depend on the progress made by the Experts *The Chancellor of the Exchequer emphasised thatif the Conference of Experts was to be postponed until July 17th we ought to insist that the FrenchGovernment should follow our. own example andintimate that they would not claim their share of the payments due by Germany on July 15thwhich were to be postponed under the terms of theHoover proposal. He agreed that the date of thePolitical Conference should depend upon the pro-gress made by the Experts.. He also agreed with aproposal by the French Government that the Confer-ence of Experts should be restricted to British,Belgian, French, Italian, Japanese, German, and,if possible, American representatives.The Cabinet agreed To approve that the meeting of experts should be arranged for july 17th, and that all matters relating to that meeting and any subsequent Conference of ministers should be left to the Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs, inconsultation with the Prime Minister,and the Chancellor of the Exchequer.
